title: @Riot Meddler, are you satisfied with the state of Varus in the modern game?
body:
He was released in May 2012. Since then as an Immobile Poke/Catch champion who's core gameplay was Poke with Q, catch a squishy with R and deal mixed damage with Blight & Blight Detonation.

But right now his niche out outclassed by the likes of Kalista and even Ashe who can engage from a safer position and poke without having to put up with an absurd channel time that also slows an already immobile AD Carry. It's really not optimal  because what you trade for that poke far outweighs the strength of the poke itself.

When I look at other AD Carries I seriously wonder why Varus was designed the way that he is. Does he really need a channel time on his Q? Should that channel time be as long as it is? Should channeling his Q really slow him? Sadly, the answer to most of these questions is something along the lines of 'back in 2012 it would be alright'. But since 2012 we've seen the introduction and rework of AD Carries such as Lucian, Tristana, Sivir, Twitch and Kalista who all have more Poke, Carry Potential and Mobility than Varus - even Kog'Maw got some love.

Now, I've played Varus a fair bit since I started playing mid-2012, and I've always liked his playstyle. But nowadays I can't afford to pick him in most situations because, despite my affinity for him, he's just straight-up outclassed in all of the roles that he half-fills. If I wanted a High-poke AD Carrry I'd probably pick Jinx or Caitlyn who are much safer and scale harder into the game. If I wanted a champion that I could use to initiate fights I would probably pick Ashe or Kalista who are also much safer where Ashe can engage from a much greater distance and Kalista is far more mobile.

replies.body: The niche we've got in mind for Varus is a combination of poke and moderate ranged initiation/counter initiation, primarily via his Q and R respectively. We've been feeling he's a bit weak at those for a while and have been gradually buffing him as a result. That's involved increased mana regen late last year to support poke and increased R width recently to improve his ult's reliability.  Additionally in the upcoming patch (5.5), we'll be changing his Q cooldown to begin at start of channel, not when he fires the arrow off. That should give him access to more Q casts late game in particular, and make charged shots (as opposed to saving the Q to proc Blight) a bit more attractive.

Have you thought/discussed removing the slow-while-channeling on his Q and/or reducing cast and channel times on his Q and E? I can understand that you'd like to make sure that there's counter-play, but don't you think him being completely immobile in the current form of the game leaves him vulnerable enough?

At least Ashe's abilities don't hinder her movement.

EDIT: I also think that proccing Blight with Q should be more of a lane phase harass/mid-game poke sort of usage with E being the primary way to proc it in a teamfight scenario. Otherwise it's like using Ace in the Hole in the middle of a teamfight - it's detrimental to your DPS. Perhaps maybe reducing the cast time (and possibly allowing it to be cast while moving) and increasing the missile speed on E could be a good way to make it more teamfight-friendly.

Obviously you can't implement all of these ideas, but considering one or two of them couldn't hurt.

The Q cooldown buff seems like it could really help 40% CDR builds.

Do you guys have any qualms if he is regularly played mid as an AD Caster (with 40% CDR) akin to Jayce instead of an ADC? I prefer to play him that way instead of as an ADC and think he could be perceived as stronger because you don't have to be focused too much with auto-attacking in the same spot as an immobile ADC.
He only has 2 AD Scaling abilities whereas Jayce has 5. Not to mention the fact that he's mobile and has an Armor Debuff Passive.

I think you're going to have a bit of trouble with this, considering that while, sure, his Q, R, and E allow him to poke and counterinitiate, as long as you've got his Innate and W eating up his power budget while being contrary to the rest of his kit (Q and E want to poke people down, and R potentially wants to keep people in E and hold them down for Q as long as possible, while Innate and W want him to constantly fire off attacks and alternate a quick tap of Q or E on every third stack). 

If you want him to own that "Poke/counterinitiation" niche (which still overlaps a bit with Ashe, but the differences are enough to distinguish them I suppose), I think you're eventually going to have to replace his Innate and W with abilities that follow the same goal as the rest of his abilities, or make them so weak that his Q, E, and R are allowed to be powerful enough to carve him into that niche.

I think a main reason he's weak is because when his ult is down, his only tool for self peel is his E. This is unlike Jinx or even Draven because one has a slow and a zoning/ root, while the other has a speed up and a knock back. Varus's E is mediocre because the slow is so little and the area can simply be dashed over by many champions. Meaning if you jump on him with his cult down, he's dead, since he can't escape from {{champion:127}}  ultimate or {{champion:120}} either. Maybe increasing the slow on E at earlier levels or allowing for some synergy with his Q where if he hits an enemy on his E they're rooted or stunned?

Yes, let's compare {{champion:110}} and {{champion:222}}. Both immobile, both have big teamfight ultimates. Here's where it changes. Jinx has longer AA range, her E is Hard CC as opposed to a mere slow, her Poke has a slow tacked onto it as well as it not having to be channeled, and she gets a massive movement speed boost on kill. Varus on the other hand gets attack speed on kill THAT JINX GETS FROM HER Q ANYWAY.

Food for thought.
I've been thinking if each of his skills had a different effect on blighted enemies Sort of like Brand). Perhaps change his W to passive.

I've always like Varus quite a bit. I used to like trying to play him mid AP but eventually gave up due to fragility/lack of sustain since spell vamp didn't work on his blight and played him AD a bit. I like the interaction between attacks and his other abilities using the blight stacks. I don't usually like burst myself, but I enjoyed the sustained pattern required to burst with his blight. I'd like to see more explored in that avenue, such as a stacking AS buff from kills to let him apply them faster and/or his ultimate snaring additional enemies faster or longer according to the blight stacks consumed on them.

As it stands, he seems a bit flat if his blight and hail of arrows are just throw-aways. Adding more situational strength to his hail could allow him to better set up an ultimate (or land a Q).
